Award.AwardTitle: Construction of the COUPP-500kg Bubble Chamber for Dark Matter Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
COUPP (The Chicagoland Observatory for Underground Particle Physics) employs room temperature bubble chambers to search for dark matter particle candidates. Following continuous 2011 operation of a chamber containing 4 kg of trifluoromethyl iodide (CF_3I) at the underground depth of SNOLAB at Sudbury, Canada, COUPP presently offers the best sensitivity to spin-dependent WIMP (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles)-nucleus couplings from any dark matter search. Dramatic progress in acoustic discrimination against alpha particles and the abatement of backgrounds has recently been made. With these new developments, COUPP should also lead the field in sensitivity to spin-independent couplings, following the installation of an already-commissioned 60 kg chamber at SNOLAB.

The level of maturity reached by this technique has prompted this collaboration to initiate the conceptual design of a 500 kg module. Detailed Monte Carlo simulations indicate that this chamber will have the ability to perform an exhaustive exploration of the vast supersymmetric WIMP parameter space. The design is to be based on a modest extrapolation of the systems already developed and tested for the 60 kg chamber. This award provides support to complete the design and development of COUPP-500.

Broader Impacts: The effort described will generate substantial broader impacts in the areas of education and mentoring. COUPP has a long history of commitment to providing undergraduates with laboratory research opportunities, through UC, IUSB and FNAL programs, and to the mentoring and promotion of graduate students and postdocs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast majority of matter in the Universe is in a form that neither absorbs nor emits light. Invisible to conventional astronomical techniques, it reveals itself through the dynamics of galaxies, clusters of galaxies, and by its impact on the evolution of the Cosmos and its structures. Many ongoing experiments are attempting to identify the nature of this ?dark matter?. Most of them revolve around specialized detection techniques aiming to identify characteristic modes of interaction from dark matter particles. Many such experiments are performed deep underground, where the rock overburden filters out known radiations originating in cosmic rays. Dark matter particles are expected to reach the laboratories? depth unaffected.

 

PICO performs one such search by revisiting an old particle detection technique, the bubble chamber. PICO operates these chambers in conditions of pressure and temperature that result in essentially only dark matter particles being able to cause bubbling in the device, which otherwise remains insensitive to the vast majority of known particles.

 

PICO chambers operate one mile underground, at the depth of the Canadian underground laboratory SNOLAB. The largest chamber built by the collaboration thus far contained 60 kg of target material, sensitive to dark matter interactions. No events were observed during several months of operation, resulting in the most sensitive constraints on a family of dark matter interaction models. These constraints educate the choice of theoretical models aiming to improve and expand our understanding of fundamental particles and their interactions. This NSF award supported the development of PICO?s experimental techniques, while also providing education, training, and professional development opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, and to postdoctoral researchers.

 

The collaboration is presently funded in Canada to build a very large (500 liter) chamber at this same underground site. The device is expected to probe the vast majority of supersymmetric extensions of the Standard Model of particle interactions able to generate good dark matter candidates. This will lead to a discovery, or alternatively, to the exclusion of this particular theory.


Last Modified: 12/09/2018
Modified by: Juan I Collar
